Want to know who contributed to this research? Check out the list of all authors and contributors from the ECB and national central banks across the euro area in the full occasional paper https://t.co/RHdEmnhi3a 
5/5

Going forward, we need:
1⃣ more data on inflation expectations held by people and firms
2⃣ a comprehensive framework for assessing (un)anchoring
3⃣ more consideration of expectation measures in forecasting models 
4/5

As well as working as standalone forecasts, we found inflation expectations can benefit forecasting when included in modelling and can inform scenario and risk analysis 
3/5

Our research suggests longer-term inflation expectations have become less well anchored in the euro area since the global financial and European debt crises, although different metrics point to conflicting signals about the timing and scale of this process
2/5

(THREAD) Measuring how people and firms expect inflation to develop is not easy. That’s why we focused on surveys of professional forecasters and on market-based indicators, such as the implications of relevant market prices https://t.co/RHdEmnhi3a 
1/5 https://t.co/4XRH7zNg7q
Working Paper: Striking a bargain - Narrative identification of wage bargaining shocks https://t.co/JiZsQnfCiw
Working Paper: A mixed frequency BVAR for the euro area labour market https://t.co/FpSAsZv4C2

Did you miss our 2021 #ECBForum on Central Banking? Check out some of the highlights with Claire Jones @senoj_erialc in the video below ⬇️
You can also watch the full sessions back on our YouTube channel https://t.co/pr3BsoX2IZ https://t.co/QYUcpwcA3F

Welcome to our Twitter mini-series, where we look in detail at the research behind our strategy review! 

For the next few Fridays, we’ll be showcasing three of the topics we looked at and explaining what we found.
 
The first topic for today is low inflation⬇️ https://t.co/VEviP77APa

Want to know who contributed to this research? Check out the list of all authors and contributors from the ECB and national central banks across the euro area in the full occasional paper https://t.co/bvGH8b0I69
4/4

Structural trends like globalisation, digitalisation and demographic factors also likely contributed to low inflation, despite not being main drivers. This is because they could not be easily offset by interest rate policy when rates were close to lower limit 
3/4

The persistently low inflation of the last decade can be attributed to a combination of factors. Cyclical developments played a substantial role, while underestimations of economic slack and the divergence of inflation expectations from our objective were also important
2/4

(THREAD) Between 2013 and 2019, average inflation in the euro area was 1%, well below our inflation target. 
We looked at the reasons behind this as part of our recently concluded strategy review https://t.co/bvGH8b0I69
1/4 https://t.co/lb3eoDJKel

Coming up from 17:45 CET: Chief Economist Philip R. Lane will join @ClevelandFed President and CEO Loretta J. Mester in the policy panel at Inflation: Drivers and Dynamics Conference 2021 https://t.co/aEi0bNtFdz https://t.co/6oJsQZwdr7

Rising inflation has intensified the debate about the persistence of price pressures, says Executive Board member @Isabel_Schnabel. High-quality research is vital to understand how inflation expectations and behavioural changes affect monetary transmission https://t.co/2FlAi9jN1J https://t.co/OU3lnXfpva

Banks should recognise climate risks, address structural challenges to their business models, and not underestimate credit risk in the wake of the pandemic, Supervisory Board member Edouard Fernandez-Bollo warns in a speech about the challenges ahead https://t.co/WrdvSA0Uag https://t.co/jqX6Kgg3hK

What would you like to ask Supervisory Board Chair Andrea Enria about our response to the pandemic? 

Join us on Saturday, 9 October at 11:00 CET for an online Q&A organised by @Europarl_EYE https://t.co/oVEbnmAhGW

#AskECB #EYE2021 https://t.co/Waf4J4FZe9 https://t.co/b0h2k3HI5F

Flexible and complementary monetary and fiscal policy helped stabilise financial markets and counter the pandemic’s impact on inflation, says Executive Board member @Isabel_Schnabel. Unusual crises require unusual responses–so long as they are proportional
https://t.co/GvW66NjWkV https://t.co/5u8qycBr2M

The 2021 #ECBForum is over! It was full of insights into the future of monetary policy and inflation. Want to know more? Tune into #TheECBPodcast where Chief Economist Philip R. Lane spoke about these topics in the context of our new strategy https://t.co/N0bbrvQNNK https://t.co/C4FVak9HLg

And the winner of this year’s young economists’ competition is… @drkaenzig, with his paper on the economic consequences of putting a price on carbon! Congratulations to Diego and all finalists on your efforts. Find out more about their research https://t.co/pfedqyh8CZ https://t.co/r4fMTT3VLr

Letter from the ECB President to Mr Gunnar Beck, MEP, on ECB communication https://t.co/FLHmkeFwoE

Cyber threats are steadily evolving. We need to remain proactive and maintain our commitment to protecting cyber resilience, says Executive Board member Fabio Panetta opening today’s strategic discussion at the Euro Cyber Resilience Board. 
Read the speech https://t.co/UVP1gMLyId https://t.co/py2jt00Ct9

LIVE: The #ECBForum on Central Banking policy panel with central bank heads Andrew Bailey, Haruhiko Kuroda, Christine @Lagarde and Jerome Powell, moderated by Alessandra Galloni (@aagalloni) https://t.co/lO1QDFQnb2

Coming up shortly: the #ECBForum policy panel with central bank heads Andrew Bailey, Haruhiko Kuroda, Christine @Lagarde and Jerome Powell, moderated by Alessandra Galloni (@aagalloni).

Watch it live here on Twitter. https://t.co/zLFqo0Uvl3

Coming up from 14:00 CET: Session 2 of the #ECBForum on Central Banking. On today’s agenda:

1⃣Structural change arising from the pandemic
2⃣The intersection of monetary policy and climate policy
3⃣Monetary policy, employment and inequality

Programme https://t.co/BY4KXDmYoU https://t.co/zIzpxjdv0J
Working Paper: Tracking growth in the euro area subject to a dimensionality problem https://t.co/2lfxDyKvHb

We have avoided any damaging cliff effects after Brexit, says Supervisory Board member Edouard Fernandez-Bollo. We must now promote high supervisory standards together with the UK and ensure that we can capture and manage all relevant risks https://t.co/taJwdbyzCb https://t.co/MY1KwUZCf5

Starting now: Session 1 of the #ECBForum on Central Banking examines corporate indebtedness following the pandemic.

Watch live on our website https://t.co/BY4KXDmYoU https://t.co/fAYZHb7Rqr

Lagarde: The key challenge is to ensure that we do not overreact to temporary supply shocks, while also nurturing the positive demand forces that could lift inflation towards our 2% target.

Read the full speech https://t.co/I7A8tzifhi

4/4

Lagarde: These trends include

1⃣ Demand side changes, e.g. people spending their extra savings
2⃣ Supply side changes, e.g. faster digitalisation 
3⃣ Faster implementation of the green transition

3/4

Lagarde: This atypical recovery is leading to rapid growth, but also to supply bottlenecks appearing unusually early in the economic cycle.

The pandemic has also introduced new trends that could produce both upward and downward price pressures.

2/4

(THREAD) The economy is back from the brink, but not out of the woods, says President Christine @Lagarde in her opening speech at the #ECBForum on Central Banking.

After an unusual recession, the euro area is going through a highly atypical recovery https://t.co/I7A8tzifhi

1/4
LIVE: President Christine @Lagarde opens the 2021 #ECBForum on Central Banking. https://t.co/SOl88Yuvce

Coming up from 14:00 CET: Day 1 of the #ECBForum on Central Banking. 

President Christine @Lagarde opens the Forum, followed by sessions on corporate indebtedness and a panel discussion on the future of inflation. 

See the programme https://t.co/BY4KXDmYoU https://t.co/1Ushf4oP23
Watch again: Lagarde at @EP_Economics on how our forward guidance is shaping inflation expectations https://t.co/XCoKHKunp8

Our annual competition gives ten young economists the opportunity to join the #ECBForum and share their fresh perspectives on today’s challenges.

Learn more about this year’s finalists and their research https://t.co/pfedqyh8CZ https://t.co/iKRlczJslm

Lagarde: I remain fully convinced of the need for an open mind to ensure that we keep delivering on our mandate in rapidly changing circumstances. We will therefore review our strategy periodically, starting in 2025.

Lagarde: financing conditions for the economy remain very favourable. That is why we set a moderately slower pace of net asset purchases under the pandemic emergency purchase programme. We remain entirely committed to preserving these favourable financing conditions.

Lagarde: there are some factors that could lead to stronger price pressures than are currently expected, but we are seeing limited signs of this risk so far. Our baseline scenario continues to foresee inflation remaining below our target over the medium term.

Lagarde: euro area inflation rose to 3% in August and we expect it to rise further this autumn. We continue to view this upswing as largely temporary. A range of factors are currently pushing up inflation. The impact of these factors should dissipate in the course of next year.

Lagarde: the economic recovery in the euro area is increasingly advanced. We expect continued strong growth in the second half of 2021 and euro area output to exceed its pre-pandemic level by the end of the year. Risks to growth are broadly balanced.
Lagarde: we have adopted a simple and clear symmetric inflation target of 2% over the medium term. It gives a well-defined yardstick to help us steer our monetary policy.

Lagarde at @EP_Economics hearing: with the conclusion of our strategy review in July we have achieved our goal of ensuring that our monetary policy framework is robust enough to meet future challenges. Underlying research has been published https://t.co/K04BrfcSbS

Live now: President @Lagarde speaks before the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs of the @Europarl_EN and answers questions from its members. Follow here https://t.co/3At3tonxVM @EP_Economics https://t.co/PgvyPx8cHD

The annual growth of household deposits stood at 7.3% in August 2021. This marks a slowdown from the peak registered in February 2021 (9.5%), following the large accumulation of deposits at the beginning of the pandemic. Read our press release https://t.co/T63cE1Hrkp https://t.co/hv4XvyYA85
How did euro area bank lending and money supply evolve in August? How do they compare with July’s figures? Find out more in the press release https://t.co/T63cE1pPVP https://t.co/JgUl2ySX3U

Tune in at 13:45 CET to watch President Christine @Lagarde speak before the Economic and Monetary Affairs Committee of the @Europarl_EN and answer questions from its members. Follow the webcast here https://t.co/3At3tonxVM @EP_Economics https://t.co/hBvSXAF5dV

Did you know that many parts of our website are available in more than one language? Select your language via the button in the top right-hand corner and explore our website in the language of your choice https://t.co/k2MLroY4Xz https://t.co/8CwOFhaHtm

Our inflation objective, measuring price changes and climate change… These are just some of the topics we looked at during our recent strategy review. In #TheECBPodcast, host @KatieRanger_ discusses the review’s outcome with Chief Economist Philip R. Lane https://t.co/YJllIOT16O https://t.co/RfHjnAbRR6

This year’s #ECBForum on Central Banking takes place next week, on 28 and 29 September. Discussions will focus on future challenges for monetary policy.

The Forum will be webcast live – check out the programme https://t.co/ePGFBnM8H0 https://t.co/ERvAaWCbux
Decisions taken by the Governing Council of the ECB (in addition to decisions setting interest rates) https://t.co/tclHmiUij5

Lagarde on slack in the euro area economy: We have at least 1 million more people unemployed today than before the pandemic. There is still a lot of ground to cover for employment to return to pre-pandemic levels, and we hope it will happen. Read more https://t.co/oqjz1GhetZ 3/3

Lagarde on our latest decisions: The lady is for calibrating, not for tapering. Our policy is to ensure favourable financing conditions to help people to cross the pandemic bridge. That’s why we calibrated our purchases to the amount we believe is necessary to achieve that 2/3

(THREAD) We are emerging from an unprecedented situation and are in an adjustment period now, President Christine @Lagarde tells @CNBC’s Annette Weisbach. We’ve seen in the past that bottlenecks in the economy are resolved over the course of time https://t.co/oqjz1GyPSz 1/3 https://t.co/bjKI6g7W0E

We need a proactive approach to the implementation of the Basel III reforms, says Supervisory Board member Edouard Fernandez-Bollo. We must also push for improvements in managing the risks that will shape the 21st century. https://t.co/4FqJKGSPah https://t.co/vByX27xLfj

Interested in the results of the economy-wide stress test? Read more:
➡️Press release https://t.co/Yq8I9JW4VL
➡️Occasional paper https://t.co/2ty8VnDdXG
➡️The ECB Podcast with Vice President Luis de Guindos, climate change centre head Irene Heemskerk https://t.co/ktx5ZnpyLu

If we do not transition toward a greener economy soon, physical risks will continue to increase, says Executive Board member @FrankElderson at the Conference on Banking Union, in comments on the recent economy-wide climate stress test results.
Full speech
https://t.co/QWcLuRWO9X https://t.co/83qpV2mmaF
Working Paper: Monetary policy, agent heterogeneity and inequality - Insights from a three-agent New Keynesian model https://t.co/jU0kzcqiEc
Working Paper: Bank balance sheet constraints and bond liquidity https://t.co/oFmQoEyUlm
Economic Bulletin box: EU emissions allowance prices in the context of the ECB’s climate change action plan https://t.co/ZO3N8JXM6I

The strong imbalance between demand and supply is evidenced by the unprecedented lengthening of suppliers’ delivery times, especially in sectors relying on transportation and on inputs from sectors where shortages have occurred 3/3

What is behind these bottlenecks? During the recovery phase of the pandemic, people bought more of certain products – including electronics. This strong surge in demand, coupled with specific supply disruptions, led to bottlenecks in global supply chains 2/3

It is estimated that euro area countries lost 6.7% of goods export volumes due to bottlenecks in supply chains in the first half of 2021. Shipping disruptions and shortages of certain products were key factors for the slump in exports https://t.co/sxmBuk20bZ #EconomicBulletin 1/3 https://t.co/VgUKk82D7l

The latest Economic Bulletin is out! The Bulletin presents the economic and monetary information which forms the basis for our policy decisions. Read more https://t.co/9KYvmd74Kd https://t.co/KyaADuUpfv

Tune in today from 11:45 CET: Executive Board member and Supervisory Board Vice-Chair @FrankElderson talks about how to integrate climate change into the tasks of central banks and supervisors. 
Register here https://t.co/VvUpE9qyzA https://t.co/BF0mr6LytM

Check out the latest episode of #TheECBPodcast with our host @katieranger_ on the results of the economy-wide climate stress test. Now also available on podlink https://t.co/YJllIOT16O https://t.co/pTy8WyCO1J

We are pleased to present a photo of the Executive Board in its current composition. Here’s the team, from left to right: Fabio Panetta, Vice-President Luis de Guindos, Isabel Schnabel, President Christine Lagarde, Frank Elderson and Philip R. Lane https://t.co/mza6bxvtMk https://t.co/23RwGgJYv9

The results of our first climate stress test were revealed today!
What are the findings? What do they mean for people, companies and banks? Find out more in #TheECBPodcast with Vice-President Luis de Guindos, Irene Heemskerk and host @katieranger_ https://t.co/ktx5ZnH9D2 https://t.co/YL4pNB7EaK

There have been signs of improvement in banks’ profitability, says Supervisory Board Chair Andrea Enria. Banks are putting in place more ambitious cost reduction measures and transforming their business strategies, often entailing consolidation https://t.co/3kjH3J9IYM https://t.co/Ug8vCxA39k

The transition to a greener economy can also be a golden opportunity. Acting early has clear benefits that outweigh the initial costs, for example as a result of energy efficiency gains for firms and cheaper energy prices https://t.co/Yq8I9JEtxb 3/3

The results show that climate risk in the euro area is concentrated in certain regions and sectors. Firms located in the regions most exposed to physical risk could face very severe and frequent natural disasters, affecting their creditworthiness. 2/3

Our first economy-wide climate stress test shows that firms and banks benefit from adopting green policies early on. We analysed the impact of climate change on more than four million firms worldwide and 1,600 euro area banks. See full results https://t.co/Yq8I9JEtxb 1/3 https://t.co/fOfihyaTRO

Firms’ liquidity was preserved during the pandemic, thanks to cash buffers and the extensive support from monetary, fiscal and supervisory authorities. Their profitability, operating efficiency and solvency, though, came under pressure https://t.co/O24ItTkGNU #EconomicBulletin https://t.co/0ggyGPxpfR
Euro area pension fund statistics (Q2 2021) https://t.co/cKjMFThnJ9

The pandemic has boosted digitalisation, says Supervisory Board Chair Andrea Enria, creating potential efficiency gains for banks. With the dwindling importance of local presence, it’s an opportunity for banks to develop their cross-border business https://t.co/4UZdr1ltiw https://t.co/prwYPWatvK
Economic Bulletin box: Liquidity conditions and monetary policy operations in the period from 28 April to 27 July 2021 https://t.co/1Wp6aks2JM

These recent spikes in inflation in the United States and the euro area can be mostly attributed to special factors that are likely to be of a temporary nature. Inflation rates are expected to fall substantially again over the first half of next year 2/2

Recent euro area and US inflation spikes are mainly driven by only a few items, with energy prices playing a key role. Excluding energy and food prices, inflation in the euro area still remains below its pre-pandemic levels https://t.co/wFYGfHPydJ #EconomicBulletin 1/2 https://t.co/5Cqi6xbzU5
Looking for something shorter and in plain language? Each topic that our strategy review covered is explained in simple terms on our website. Take a look https://t.co/luaJTTVMj3

We have published several papers which provided input for our recent strategy review. Our review covered various topics linked to monetary policy and the economy and the papers’ contents fed into the Governing Council’s discussions on each topic. Read more https://t.co/K04BreVgNi https://t.co/wQgHu5nn4L

As financial markets calm and the economic outlook improves, there has been a gradual shift in the way asset purchases benefit the economy and inflation, says @Isabel_Schnabel @LatvijasBanka’s Economic Conference. 
Read full speech https://t.co/6e2TOI7vaL https://t.co/QMnycUoiHD

The recalibration of TLTRO III during the pandemic enabled one of the largest liquidity injections in the history of the ECB. It helped banks secure funding under favourable terms to support access to credit for firms and people https://t.co/Z465gl7v3P #EconomicBulletin https://t.co/q0WnfihzZx

Watch live today from 12:30 CET: Executive Board member @Isabel_Schnabel talks about the changing role of asset purchases from crisis to recovery at @LatvijasBanka’s Sustainable Economy in Times of Change conference https://t.co/bf8PhFtrjq

Changes in hours worked can offer flexibility in the labour market that helps to withstand shocks during economic downturns. This feature is also an important factor in assessing how strong the labour market is during subsequent recoveries 3/3
